headline: Chef John's Perfect Prime Rib
description: Use Chef John's easy "mathematical method," and you'll get the best prime rib, cooked to a perfect medium rare, every time.

video.description: See a fool-proof method for making flawless prime rib.
video.name: Perfect Prime Rib

name: Chef John's Perfect Prime Rib

recipeInstructions.text: Place prime rib roast on a plate and bring to room temperature, 2 to 4 hours.
Preheat the oven to 500 degrees F (260 degrees C).
Combine butter, pepper, and herbes de Provence in a bowl; mix until well blended. Spread butter mixture evenly over entire roast. Season roast generously with kosher salt.
Roast the 4-pound roast in the preheated oven for 20 minutes. (If your roast is larger or smaller than 4 pounds, multiply the exact weight times 5 minutes.)
Turn the oven off and, leaving the roast in the oven with the door closed, let the roast sit in the oven for 2 hours.
Remove roast from the oven, slice, and serve.

review.reviewBody: Works like magic.
I use a different coating, but using the times set out by Chef John has always produced a perfect prime rib no matter the size. Another Chef John recipe we both love. Thanks again Chef John.
I changed the flavored butter, I used Grace Jamaican jerk seasoning mixed in with the soft butter to give it a little kick. You can use hot, regular, or mild, depending on how you like your heat.
Made this many times and comes out perfectly everytime!!

This is a fantastic recipe. I have been making them this way for decades and always turn out perfectly. FOR THE 1 STAR REVIEW BELOW... this person claimed to follow directions completely but DID NOT. They just heated oven to 500 , put roast in and shut oven off immediatly. They missed the most important part of cooking at 500 for 5 min per lb. Guys, if you cannot follow directions, do not then come back and claim it was bad. Maybe take time to re-read? If you follow the 5 min per lb at 500, then NEVER OPEN OVEN DOOR for an additional 2 hours after you shut off the oven, you will have amazing prime rib. NEVER OPEN THAT OVEN DOOR PERIOD. If you do, you ruin a very costly piece of meat.
Amazing recipe!

The first time I made it, we found it a bit too rare so we increased the time to six and a half minutes per pound and ended up with an internal temperature of 132F. That turned out perfect to our liking. We used the rarest parts of the first attempt for a stir-fry so that didn't go to waste
I have made this for the last 3 years and I followed it exactly and it has turned out every time! Thanks Chef John
This recipe worked perfectly to make absolutely delicious prime rib.

This is the perfect prime rib recipe. It is truly foolproof! We make it every Christmas and it always turns out perfectly. We have sensitive smoke alarms, so we open doors and windows when we take it out. Honestly, this doesn't matter. The prime rib is so good, who cares about a little smoke.
I LOVE the way my prime rib came out!! It was perfect!!!

You can't help but worry about your expensive cut of beef when trying a new recipe, but it turned out perfect! I couldn't wait quite the alotted time to try it so I took it out 15 minutes early. It worked out fine because I like rare. I am making another one today! I rubbed some garlic and salt on all sides and skipped the butter spread in the video.
I would let it sit in the oven a bit longer to get the internal temperature to about 128 degrees. Mine was just a little too rare closer to the bone. It was very tender.

Past attempts to make a Prime Rib Roast have been total disaster. I studied the recipe and watched the video several times. I followed the method exactly and it came out perfect! My guests were amazed and it was delicious. One guest wanted it more on the medium well so I placed it in a pan and covered it with au jus (made from a mix) to the way he wanted it. This method works well for reheating leftovers. Highly recommend this and use a thermometer probe and watch the temperature. Do not be tempted to turn the oven back on!!
This was amazing. My very first time trying to make prime rib and this worked perfectly.
Mostly followed instructions for 2.7 lb roast. Cooked a little longer at 20 min, then 300 for two hours. Came out medium. But is was so good (I like rare), tender and juicy.

Absolutely PERFECT! This was the easiest and perfect recipe. My only change was using butter, garlic salt, pepper and parsley in place of the rub seasoning recommended. My husband even said "laminate that recipe" after the first bite.

I made it. I had the meat thermometer in it. One side was perfect the other side was cooked more. It was more than 14 pounds. I think I put it in the oven incorrectly. It was not distributing the heat evenly.

It was done to perfection! Used the temperature probe and took the meat out of the oven at 130°. It only took just under an hour to reach temperature. Thank you, will definitely use this method again.

After cooking our prime rib encrusted in salt method for years....I decided to try something different. This method is AMAZING!!! Perfectly mid-rare from end to end. Amazing flavor. I didn't have the seasoning it calls for so I used Montreal Steak seasoning and it was so yummy we've used it each time. Easy, peasy and FULL of flavor!!
First time making prime rib and was a huge success! Family loved it! Highly recommended

WARNING! We have an oven with a cooling fan as mentioned in the instructions. We turned it off at the breaker as recommended. DO NOT DO THIS! We found out from the repairman that the fan is to cool the control panel not the oven. After we cooked our roast at 500*, we turned it off at the breaker. When we flipped the breaker back on, the oven didn't come on. The fuse had blow because of the heat build up in the control panel. $360 later......... Our prime rib was delicious though!
I got rave reviews on this recipe. It came out EXACTLY like Chef John described and everyone loved it. The crust was amazing too! PS: Our prime rib came in at 12lbs.
I made this with a boneless roast and it came out perfect. Does it work the same with a bone-in? The bones add weight so how does that affect the initial roasting time?
This too all the thinking out of cooking this grand piece of meat. Remember to let it rest out of the oven before cutting. I also made Chef John's aus jus. Easy Peesy and the whole meal was fabo!!

Oh my goodness this is amazing! Your instructions are spot on! It’s just the two of us now and didn’t want to miss out on prime rib.. I bought a 6.690 standing rib and had it cut in half. 3.345 lbs x 5 minutes = 17 minutes rounded up and I set the oven to cut off. It only took about 1 hour and 15 minutes to reach the perfect medium rare. My husband thanks you (I do too)for sharing your recipe! We will enjoy the other half very soon.

Just made the largest prime rib I have ever done with this method.. 13.83 pounds. Results were once again, spectacular! I chopped a pod of garlic and mixed it in with 1 cup (2 sticks) of butter to coat the meat. I took out the roast to get to room temp around 7pm the night before and put it in the oven at 1pm. 500 for right at an hour gave 4 min 20 sec per pound, then didn't open the oven for 2 hours 20 min (20 min was more because didn't quite have everything else ready). Have a newer range so had to unplug it otherwise the fan would have come on. I thought about setting the oven at 350 so I would know when the oven temp was 350 ( and maybe keep the temp there for 20 min or so) but didn't and just let it ride. Had I done that, the roast would have been a little less rare which would have been ok too, but I personally like it more rare. It also would have been able to take another few minutes at 500, but I certainly didn't want to ruin the roast by leaving it that hot too long. I didn't use a meat thermometer, as mine melted during the process.. lol
This was so easy and fabulous!

I followed the recipe exactly as it is and it was the most delicious, perfectly cooked prime rib roast EVER! It was by far better looking and much more flavorful than any of our favorite restaurants serve, and that's saying a lot! First of all, the "mathematical method" is just genius and it really works. My roast was done to perfection with a nice, crispy crust along the outer edge. When you bite into it, you get the cruncy flavor, followed by the tender, juicy meat inside and it's just awesome! I followed up with Chef John's au just recipe and it was great as well. I'll be using this recipe forever - it's the gold standard!!

This can work if you have less than optimal conditions. I only have an old countertop roaster oven and its highest temp. is 450. My kitchen is cold in winter so I left the roast (10#, 4 ribs) out overnight and roasted it for one hour at 450 then let it sit for 2 hours. Came out just bordering on rare, which is how I like it.
This is truly bulletproof. We had a 9 lb roast, so cooked a little more than 45 mins. Also added porcini mushroom powder to the butter.
Mine came out too rare using this method. It was a 3 lb roast, 15 minutes @500°.

Absolutely 💯 perfect and scrumptious. Did have to flip circuit breaker off on the Jenn Air ovens to prevent a fast cool down, so thank you so much for covering the fan issue in your narrative. Used rub that was fresh Rosemary and Oregano from garden and fresh cracked black pepper in the butter. Our rib roast was very tender and completely devoured Christmas 🎄 day.

Perfect method for cooking the most tender and juicy prime rib! Follow the directions carefully and you will LOVE the results! Be sure to season VERY liberally because it is a big cut of meat. Definitely let it come to room temperature before cooking to ensure perfect results 😋
I have made this a couple of times per year for the last 5 years. It never disappoints! I followed Carlos' advice because our oven cools down too quickly and it is perfect.

perfection. The pic says everything. As was noted if your oven has a fan that pops on once the 500 F cook time is over.....go turn off the breaker so fan does not cool off oven too soon. And no peeking!

Followed the receipt to the letter. Meat was raw after the 2 hours in the turned off oven. Has to heat up the oven again to come to 125. Had to wait another 2 hours until we could eat! Never again! I will stick to my method next time !

I followed your recipe to a T including a thermometer probe inserted to the center of the prime rib roast. It looked and smelled wonderful until I sliced into it. 80% was rare and the center was downright raw. With no time to spare I had to micro wave the sliced roast. The result was a little bit of pink on the inside and shoe leather on the outside. The guests didn't eat very much of it. Next time I'll stick to my old cook book.

Better than any restaurant prime rib I've ever had. Crust was beyond my expectations, savory, crunchy with a wonderful layer of, melt in your mouth fat. Interior doneness was perfect medium/rare and tender. I used a choice cut standing rib roast. I cut off the bones so I could add seasoning then tied it back together. If you are using a choice cut, I recommend that you look for one that has the nicest marbling. For the best crust, store the seasoned roast on a rack in your fridge for a few days (mine stayed for 10 days). Always use a meat thermometer as my roast reached my ideal internal temperature before the 2 hour mark. Thanks Chef John.
Absolute perfection!
Works every time, provided you bring the interior temperature to room temperature. I missed this step once and had to fire up the oven after the 2 hours o0therwise my roast was going to be very rare.

I was nervous preparing a 12 pound roast as it sat at room temp for 6 hours and the center was 49* when put it into the 500* oven. Well, this turned out perfect medium rare. It was tempting to add time but stuck to the recipe and was rewarded!
This method never fails me

I made a 9.99 pound roast . I let it rest for 5 hours out of the refrigerator. I softened 2 sticks of butter,2 teaspoon Herbs de Provence,2 TBSP fresh ground pepper and mixed that well. Coated roast and sprinkled generous amount of sea salt on roast. I used a covered cookie sheet with a flat wire rack. My calculated time was 53 minutes. I baked it for 53 minutes at 500 degrees. Shut oven off for 1/2 hour . Put oven back on for 1 hour at 275degrees . Shut oven off again for 1/2 hour. Never opening oven door. It came out spectacular for our liking. The end pieces were medium and the center was medium rare. My husband said he likes it more rare. Next time I will reduce initial cooking time to 49-50 minutes. I think I will also spray coating with olive oil to reduce initial smoking from high heat. Otherwise it was delicious and easy! A crowd pleaser for 6 healthy appetites with plenty of leftovers! I made a 4 pound last Christmas and it was perfect following my same calculations then turning oven off for 1/2 hour ,turn oven on 275 for 1 hour then off again for 1/2,then taking the roast out. Of never opening the oven door . Great recipe! Will make again soon. Our local shop rite had the meat on sale ( prime angus $6.47/pound)

This is a horrible recipe for a number of reasons. It ruined what would have been a wonderful XMAS family get together. I followed the recipe religiously, and the result was an overcooked, dry piece of $125 meat that everyone ate in silence ignoring the obvious elephant in the room. There were several major problems: (1) As recommended, I used a stand-alone oven thermometer to set and hold the temperature at 500 degF for 39 minutes (for a 7lb 13 oz prime rib). At this temperature, and this duration the oven generated so much smoke that I was afraid the house smoke alarms would go off. I ended up putting a fan in the kitchen to blow out the smoke. (2) After 39 minutes I turned off the oven, and kept the oven door closed for two hours. (3) Because of the instructions called for "leave the oven closed for 2 hours", I was unable to monitor how much cooking was occurring during this interim. Since different ovens cool down at different rates, I had no way of knowing (without opening the oven door and using a thermometer) to see how much cooking was occurring during this two hour period. (4) After 2 hours, with no assessment of how things were going, I opened the oven door to a disaster. Overcooked, dry meat, and not happy friends and family sitting down to a once-a-year family get together. I will never use this recipe again. Lessons learned: (1) Sear the meat at high temperature at the start (2) Reduce the temperature and cook the remainder of the meat at lower temperature (3) Most importantly: MONITOR THE COOKING USING A TEMPERATURE GAGE BY OPENING THE OVEN AND CHECKING CONTINUOULSY DURING THE COOKING CYCLE! Any recipe which calls for leaving the meat unattended (and un-measured for two hours without having the ability to open the oven door and taking a temperature measurement should be immediately discarded)

I followed the recipe to the T. Roast was at room temperature. But after 2 hrs of shutting the oven, the roast came out too cooked. It was medium cooked as opposed to medium rare. I think this recipe reply depends on the oven u have, whether your oven holds heat and how quickly it cools down. I would recommend cooking using a thermometer to properly roast the rib.

Followed the recipe almost exactly. My oven has a fan, so I could not let it rest. Instead I turned the oven as low as posslble (170 ish) and my 7.4 pound roast cooked in less then 2 hours. I also used a digital thermostat with an alarming probe. I shut the oven off when it reached 125 degrees. I also cleaned my oven ahead of time. It was amazing!!!!

Was Leary. I Have tried several options in past with inconsistent results. Easy to follow directions. Turned out perfect. Definitely top notch final product. Have newer oven. Maybe bad reviews came from older ovens
I've used this method for 2 years now at Christmas. Easy and effective. I don't even use a meat thermometer!

I changed the recipe slightly. I used a pre-made rub for Prime Rub. Also, my oven is newer and has some of the more advanced features for cooling. I did the 5 minutes per pound at 500, then let it sit in the oven off for 2 hours. The meat temp started to slow, so I kicked the oven back on to 300 until it preheated, then turned it off. Let it rest 40 minutes. For the last 20 minutes I preheated again to 400, then let it rest until it reached 140. Took the prime rib out, removed the bone, let it sit for 10 minutes, and sliced. It was perfect.
I cooked a 6 lb bone in and took it out 5 hours before and it came out perfect. I have a new oven with the auto cool down fan so just turned off the breaker after 30 mins at 500 degrees.

Perfection! We were really nervous since this was our first prime rib roast and we wanted to make sure it came out med. rare as we like it. We followed the instructions precisely, including flipping the breaker switch to the oven since our model automatically cools after it’s turned off. It was perfect! We did not have smoke during the roasting stage because the roasting pan we selected fit to the size of the roast. We are thinking a larger roasting pan would’ve caused the drippings to spread along the bottom of the pan and burn. Our confidence has been raised, and we are now looking forward to inviting others over to serve prime rib! Thank you for sharing your detailed recipe!

Well it didn’t work. Set roast out 8 hours before cooking to make sure it was room temp. Followed directions to the T. Don’t have a cooling fan in my oven, used a meat thermometer and still came out raw. I’ll cook it the way I normally do tomorrow after all, I’ve got a bunch of raw meat to work with.
I had a 5 pound roast so cooked for 25 minutes. Next time I will do 20 because most of the meat was medium and not medium rare. It was still delicious though.

Sounded like a good idea. But after 22 minutes at 500 and 2 hours in the oven, my 4 pound roast was barely cooked. Beware, if you have an oven that doesn’t hold heat, this isn’t the recipe for you. It’s Christmas and we may get to eat after 8 pm when it finally comes out of a hot oven.
I’ve made this several years ! This was the largest I’ve ever made. Just a little over ten pounds. Just follow the directions for the perfect prime rib.
Followed Chef John's instructions but no bone-in. It turned out wonderfully and excellent flavor.
This is the 2nd year I’ve made this for Christmas Dinner. It was perfect each time and so easy to make

Made this last night and it came out wonderful. I had a 10.55lb bone in roast. I missed the step where it needed 6hours+ to come to room temp. ended up sitting about 4 hours and then I *had to cook it even though the center was 50 degrees. Took it out after the 2 hours oven off and it was at 125. The only hard part was I still needed an additional hour of oven time to cook the rest of my sides so it had to sit and rest more. I cleaned my oven first to cut down on smoke and I think that helped. Would definitely do this method again.

I didn't put all the butter and herbs on the outside, in fact, I saw this cooking method AFTER I rubbed the roast and had it in the fridge over night. I panicked because I lost the recipe I was following, so I thought, this one has simple math? What the heck! So I followed the cooking instructions and yes, I was nervous, but my 19 pound roast turned out perfectly done! Thank you! I'll definitely do this again!
works every time!!!!!
I love making my prime rib using this method. It’s perfect for everyone. Rare to well done. Only way to make it.
This is my go to recipe! ALWAYS absolutely perfect!!
Worked like a champ, put it in and didn't open the door until the probe was at 145 (our preference). Smoked a lot , just turn on the fan on and smoke on. First time cooking a Prime Rib.
It was so good-no one believed I made it.

I’ve made this prime rib recipe every year for the last 5 years and it turns out perfect every time!! Not too rare, great flavor and super tender. I add a tiny amount of beef broth at the bottom so the butter doesn’t burn. For my guests who like it pink, I add a few extra minutes cooking at 500 before shutting the temp off. I get rave reviews every time from my guests. Thank you!!
Chief John’s recipe is outstanding! I’ve Never had a prime rib turn out this well. Company raved about it being the BEST prime rib they’ve ever tasted! Thank you for a successful dinner!

I've been doing this exact method of "no peek" for 25 years. To count how many times, its probably 60 times to date. It works, though the first time you do it, you will be nervous. My dear, late friend tried it her first time and must have called me a half dozen times for reassurance, each time, having had a little more to drink, LOL I've even done this for my husband's work, where it was our gift to staff to fix 2 whole, 7 rib roasts & all the fixings, roasting them in electric roaster pans, which will only work if you insulate the lids really well. Trust this method! If it doesn't work, though you are certain you followed the method to a "T", I would suggest you need to confirm your oven temperature. Also, MANY ovens, especially older ones, don't go up to 500°, so that would require refiguring your times. When I still had teenagers in the house, I would duct tape the oven door, reminding them that YOU CANNOT OPEN THE OVEN DOOR!
I've made this recipe many times. Sometimes I change up the herbs, but it always comes out of perfect medium rare.
I have made this several times and always turns out amazing and so easy to do. Thanks for sharing

I have made this recipe eight times so far, going for number nine tonight, I keep thinking it's not gonna work, but so far I have eaten a perfect prime rib every single time. Not always the same weight, but that doesn't matter, 5 min. Per pound, then two hours. And Pure excellence!! My husband and I have a romantic prime rib dinner for Christmas Eve every year, after years of wondering if I overcooked the meat, I made this recipe, and now serve prime rib two or three times a year. Honestly the best way to cook prime rib with no worries about it being over cooked. Thanks!!

New ovens with fan must be turned off by either unplugging the oven or turning off breaker for oven. I have made this at least 10 times and it always comes out perfect, but when the cooking portion is over, I flip off the breaker so the oven won't cool down.
Absolutely perfect
I've used this recipe for Christmas dinner the last 3 years and the rib has come out perfect every time best recipe ever

I have made this recipe for 5 years. Every Christmas I get a Prime Rib Roast and yes it smokes the house up? SO WHAT? I put my doggies up and open a few windows and no harm no foul. Adapt and overcome! This Prime Rib is delicious and I eat off of it for an entire week! LOVE!
I make this every year and this recipe is wonderful! Perfect everytime! Thank you Chef John!
Works every time. Been doing it this way for years and it never disappoints. Thanks Chef John!

This Christmas will be the third time I have used this recipe and followed the recipe to the letter. My family loves it. They usually aren't fans of rare beef and while this is pink and juicy, it isn't rare. It is exactly like I have gotten at restaurants. HappyHolidays.

Best prime rib cooking method. Absolutely delicious. Had a 6lb roast. Took the roast out of fridge at 12pm and let it sit for 5hours. Did thirty minutes at 500F and then oven off for two hours. It came out like this. Yum
This deserves 10 stars. Absolutely great. I also use his gravy recipe as well. Chef John is my go to!
I have followed this recipe for a number of years. It is DELICIOUS! Definitely perfect!
My go to every time. Absolutely perfect, from a 4lb to an 8lb, just calculate your time, room temp beef, turn oven off after cooking time and DO NOT OPEN THE OVEN DOOR until it is time to do so.
It was easy to make, easy to prep, just make sure your prime rib is internal temperature of 70°-75° prior to cooking in 500° oven, must be room temperature prior to cooking.

This is hands down the way to cook a prime rib (aside from using a rotisserie). However if your oven isn’t sparkling clean, you might set off fire alarms. Read that issue from some of the one star reviewers.
Came out great! I added 8 minutes to the cooking time before shutting off the oven. It came out perfectly pink, just how we like it! This is my go-to recipe now for prime rib, yum!

Our roast was absolutely beautiful and a very nice pink color throughout! Re-heated left-overs did not overcook either! Win Win! While the roast was going through its 2 hours, I made all my sides in the air fryer. Such a stress-free experience! Will definitely be making this again!
Best Prime Rib Ever !!!!!
This delicious prime rib has earned it's spot in our Christmas eve tradition dinner!

This is best used for smaller prime rib (4-5lbs). Method x worked great for me in the past with smaller prime rib but this year I'm cooking a 17lb 5 bone-in prime rib and that initial cook time is 85 mins at 500. That's going to overcook the cap on it.

I cook a lot of meat and steaks. Particularly, tomahawks. However, I had never made a prime rib. I tried this method, and it was 100% spot on. Publix had their Prime Rib on sale for Christmas for $5.79/lb, yes, you read that right. It's normally over $14/lb. So I bought 3 more. I can't wait to make my next one.
The very best, the easiest way to cook a prime rib. Change nothing. Follow instructions to a T & you’ll never cook a prime rib any differently. Superb!!!

ABSOLUTELY OUTSTANDING! Just like at a restaurant ! Def medium rare just like it says. So perfect. We did a trial run and will be making it Christmas Eve. If anyone wanted more well done, I would take a slice and cook more in a pan. How does everyone make side dishes if you aren’t able to open the oven?
I’ve made my prime rib this way for the last 5 years and it’s been perfect every time. Everyone gets their meat just the way they like it from well done on the ends to rare in the center.
I discovered this recipe several years ago and it is perfect ever time!
This is a fool proof recipe, I love rare and my wife loves well done, drop hers in the hot au ju for a few minutes, perfect for her and perfect for me. Best left overs ever!
I liked it, but prefer a little more well-done.
Perfect as is.
I saw this recipe about 4 years ago and I've been making for Christmas ever since!! It's so good and full proof you CANNOT mess it up! It's a big hit with my family. Thank you Chef John 😊
Perfect perfect. I didn't change a thing -
